title: Tidy human mortality data
text: R-package fetches organises human mortality data Human Mortality Database tidy fashion. richer complete package, look demography package. mortality package modern re-imagination extension functions hmd.mx, hmd.e0, hmd.pop demography package. Specifically: import RCurl replaced curl latter modern version former zero import, fetched data special type tibble, called humble (think human life short stay humble â€“ okay, â€™ll see way ðŸ˜…), instead list class demogdata, grabs data just period 1x1, provides data long wide format sex, provides helper function, as_demogdata, convert Mx exposure table hmd.mx output (.e.Â demogdata), provides helper function convert demogdata humble table (implemented yet).

title: Tidy human mortality data
text: first need register user (havenâ€™t already) Human Mortality Database. now set session username password, fill details run code. Alternatively, can store username password .Renviron file containing : simply just run command just getting data: data obtained via hmd_data(). function offers support multiple countries: multiple statistics: relabeling countries like : can also get different age year range: Now also supports getting data long format sex variable:
code: library(mortality) hmd_session(username = <YOUR USERNAME>,             password = <YOUR PASSWORD>) HMD_USERNAME=<YOUR USERNAME> HMD_PASSWORD=<YOUR PASSWORD> hmd_session() hmd_data("AUS", stats = "death") #> # A humble:  10,989 x 6 #> # Countries: AUS #> # Year:      1921-2019 #> # Age:       0-110 #>     year   age death_female death_male death_total country #>    <int> <int>        <dbl>      <dbl>       <dbl> <chr>   #>  1  1921     0       3842.      5125.        8967. AUS     #>  2  1921     1        719.       890.        1610. AUS     #>  3  1921     2        330.       359.         689. AUS     #>  4  1921     3        166.       250.         416. AUS     #>  5  1921     4        190.       197.         387. AUS     #>  6  1921     5        149.       153.         302. AUS     #>  7  1921     6        150.       137.         287. AUS     #>  8  1921     7        109.       118.         227. AUS     #>  9  1921     8         81.0      114.         195. AUS     #> 10  1921     9         78.0       82.2        160. AUS     #> # â€¦ with 10,979 more rows hmd_data(c("AUS", "JPN"), stats = "death") #> # A humble:  19,203 x 6 #> # Countries: AUS, JPN #> # Year:      1921-2020 #> # Age:       0-110 #>     year   age death_female death_male death_total country #>    <int> <int>        <dbl>      <dbl>       <dbl> <chr>   #>  1  1921     0       3842.      5125.        8967. AUS     #>  2  1921     1        719.       890.        1610. AUS     #>  3  1921     2        330.       359.         689. AUS     #>  4  1921     3        166.       250.         416. AUS     #>  5  1921     4        190.       197.         387. AUS     #>  6  1921     5        149.       153.         302. AUS     #>  7  1921     6        150.       137.         287. AUS     #>  8  1921     7        109.       118.         227. AUS     #>  9  1921     8         81.0      114.         195. AUS     #> 10  1921     9         78.0       82.2        160. AUS     #> # â€¦ with 19,193 more rows hmd_data(c("AUS", "JPN"), stats = c("death", "death_rate")) #> # A humble:  19,203 x 9 #> # Countries: AUS, JPN #> # Year:      1921-2020 #> # Age:       0-110 #>     year   age country death_female death_male death_total deathrate_female #>    <int> <int> <chr>          <dbl>      <dbl>       <dbl>            <dbl> #>  1  1921     0 AUS           3842.     5125.       8967.            0.0600  #>  2  1921     1 AUS            719.      890.       1610.            0.0121  #>  3  1921    10 AUS             69.0      85.2       154.            0.00125 #>  4  1921   100 AUS              2         6.02        8.02          0.170   #>  5  1921   101 AUS              5         4.01        9.01          0.560   #>  6  1921   102 AUS              2         1           3             0.453   #>  7  1921   103 AUS              0         1           1             0       #>  8  1921   104 AUS              1         1           2             1.04    #>  9  1921   105 AUS              0         0           0            NA       #> 10  1921   106 AUS              0         0           0            NA       #> # â€¦ with 19,193 more rows, and 2 more variables: deathrate_male <dbl>, #> #   deathrate_total <dbl> hmd_data(c("Australia" = "AUS", "Japan" = "JPN"), stats = "population") #> # A humble:  19,536 x 6 #> # Countries: Australia, Japan #> # Year:      1921-2021 #> # Age:       0-110 #>    year    age pop_female pop_male pop_total country   #>    <chr> <int>      <dbl>    <dbl>     <dbl> <chr>     #>  1 1921      0     62848.   65851.   128699. Australia #>  2 1921      1     57777.   60217.   117994. Australia #>  3 1921      2     56941.   59047.   115988. Australia #>  4 1921      3     58272.   60218.   118490. Australia #>  5 1921      4     58719.   60773.   119492. Australia #>  6 1921      5     59888.   61687.   121574. Australia #>  7 1921      6     61034.   62333.   123366. Australia #>  8 1921      7     59455.   60776.   120231. Australia #>  9 1921      8     57736.   58806.   116542. Australia #> 10 1921      9     56181.   57140.   113321. Australia #> # â€¦ with 19,526 more rows hmd_data(c("Australia" = "AUS", "Japan" = "JPN"),           stats = "exposure_to_risk", year_range = 5, age_range = 5) #> # A humble:  840 x 6 #> # Countries: Australia, Japan #>    year_range_5 age_range_5 exprisk_female exprisk_male exprisk_total country   #>          <itvl>      <itvl>          <dbl>        <dbl>         <dbl> <chr>     #>  1    1921-1924           0        256600.      267063.       523663. Australia #>  2    1921-1924         1-4        957177.      994721.      1951898. Australia #>  3    1921-1924         5-9       1180057.     1213273.      2393330. Australia #>  4    1921-1924       10-14       1096076.     1123037.      2219113. Australia #>  5    1921-1924       15-19        968522.      997946.      1966469. Australia #>  6    1921-1924       20-24        925053.      914989.      1840042. Australia #>  7    1921-1924       25-29        941637.      894549.      1836186. Australia #>  8    1921-1924       30-34        915723.      926174.      1841897. Australia #>  9    1921-1924       35-39        806054.      842748.      1648803. Australia #> 10    1921-1924       40-44        681851.      719764.      1401615. Australia #> # â€¦ with 830 more rows hmd_data(c("AUS", "JPN"), sex_format = "long") #> # A humble:  57,609 x 5 #> # Countries: AUS, JPN #> # Year:      1921-2020 #> # Age:       0-110 #>     year   age country deathrate sex    #>    <int> <int> <chr>       <dbl> <chr>  #>  1  1921     0 AUS       0.0600  female #>  2  1921     1 AUS       0.0121  female #>  3  1921     2 AUS       0.00578 female #>  4  1921     3 AUS       0.00289 female #>  5  1921     4 AUS       0.00325 female #>  6  1921     5 AUS       0.00252 female #>  7  1921     6 AUS       0.00248 female #>  8  1921     7 AUS       0.00181 female #>  9  1921     8 AUS       0.00138 female #> 10  1921     9 AUS       0.00137 female #> # â€¦ with 57,599 more rows

title: Tidy human mortality data
text: demography HMDHFDplus MortalityLaws tidylife (note: developmental) raw actuar ActuDistns (note: archived CRAN) CompLognormal lifecontingencies ChainLadder ELT DCL MRMR (note: archived CRAN) lossDev (note: archived CRAN)

what: Convert the death rate humble data to demogdata â€” as_demogdata
title: Convert the death rate humble data to demogdata â€” as_demogdata
text: Note data containly one country supply country select country argument.

title: Convert the death rate humble data to demogdata â€” as_demogdata
Convert the death rate humble data to demogdata â€” as_demogdata
text: data humble object hmd_data() stats = c("death_rate", "exposures_to_risk"). country single country within data. data contains single country, need supply .

what: Fetch the data from the Human Mortality Database â€” hmd_data
title: Fetch the data from the Human Mortality Database â€” hmd_data
text: hmd_data() fetches data multiple statistics merge together output. functions grab particular (set ) statistics Human Mortality Database (mortality.org). need register account mortality.org get data call hmd_session() first using functions.

title: Fetch the data from the Human Mortality Database â€” hmd_data
code: hmd_data(   country,   stats = "death_rate",   sex_format = c("wide", "long"),   year_range = 1,   age_range = 1 )  hmd_life_expectancy(country, sex_format = c("wide", "long"), year_range = 1)  hmd_birth(country, sex_format = c("wide", "long"))  hmd_life_table(   country,   sex_format = c("wide", "long"),   age_range = 1,   year_range = 1 )  hmd_population(country, sex_format = c("wide", "long"), age_range = 1)  hmd_death(   country,   sex_format = c("wide", "long"),   age_range = 1,   year_range = 1 )  hmd_exposure_to_risk(   country,   sex_format = c("wide", "long"),   age_range = 1,   year_range = 1 )  hmd_death_rate(   country,   sex_format = c("wide", "long"),   age_range = 1,   year_range = 1 )

title: Fetch the data from the Human Mortality Database â€” hmd_data
text: country country code fetch data . input may named unnamed character vector. vector named, name used label. stats statistics extract. available statistics : "birth", "death", "life_expectancy", "exposure_to_risk", "population", "life_tables", "death_rate". sex_format logical value indicate whether sex returned "long" "wide" format. default "wide". range_year, range_age single integer indicating period cohort year/age range. Generally, 1, 5 10 available.

title: Fetch the data from the Human Mortality Database â€” hmd_data

what: Set the username and password to access the Human Mortality Database â€” hmd_session
title: Set the username and password to access the Human Mortality Database â€” hmd_session
text: first need register user (already) Human Mortality Database. now set session pass username password account alternatively, can store username password .Renviron file containing HMD_USERNAME=<USERNAME> HMD_PASSWORD=<PASSWORD>

title: Set the username and password to access the Human Mortality Database â€” hmd_session
Set the username and password to access the Human Mortality Database â€” hmd_session
text: username username (typically email) signed HMD. password password used access HMD.
